data.description_suggestion: Validates and retrieves information about an OAuth2 access token. Accepts either an access_token or id_token parameter. Returns token metadata including token type, expiration, scope, and associated user information. Useful for verifying token validity and extracting token claims without making additional API calls.
data.reasoning: Operation has no summary or description, making it impossible for AI agents to understand its purpose. Added clear action verb (Validate), specified inputs (access_token or id_token parameters), outputs (token metadata), and use case context for AI agent interpretability.

message: Operation 'oauth2.userinfo.get' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, vague_description, unclear_purpose, missing_input_details, missing_output_details, poor_ai_interpretability. Operation lacks both summary and description. Added action-oriented summary, clarified authentication requirements, specified return type (Userinfo schema), and explained the operation's role in the OAuth2 flow for better AI agent understanding.

data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the authenticated end-user's profile information from Google. Requires OAuth2 authentication (implicit or authorization code flow). Returns a Userinfo object containing user identity details such as email, name, picture, and other profile attributes. This endpoint is used to obtain user information after successful OAuth2 authorization.
data.reasoning: Operation lacks both summary and description. Added action-oriented summary, clarified authentication requirements, specified return type (Userinfo schema), and explained the operation's role in the OAuth2 flow for better AI agent understanding.

data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the profile information of the currently authenticated user. This is the v2 endpoint for accessing the authenticated user's identity details. Requires OAuth2 authentication. Returns a Userinfo object containing user attributes including email, name, picture, and other profile information. The '/me' path segment represents the authenticated user making the request.
